editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: Amends for ladies. With the humour of roaring. A comedy. As it was acted at the black friars, both by the prince's servants, and the lady Elizabeth's.
London: printed by G. eld, for Math. Walbancke, and are to be sold at his shop, at the new gate of Grays-inn, or at the old. 1618.

div.head: Amends for ladies.
A comedy.
Actus primi scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter the lady honour, the lady perfect, the lady bright.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: A wife the happiest state? It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Yes, such a wife as I, that have a man
As if myself had made him: such a one
As I may justly say, I am the rib
Belonging to his breast. Widow and maid,
Your lives compared to mine are miserable,
Though wealth and beauty meet in each of you.
Poor virgin, all thy sport is thought of love,
And meditation of a man, the time
And circumstance ere thou canst fix thy thoughts
On one thy fancy will approve.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: That trouble already may be passed.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Why if it be.
The doubt, he will not hold his brittle faith,
That he is not a compatible choice,
And so your noble friends will cross the match,
Doth make your happiness uncertain still:
or say you married him, what he would prove.
Can you compare your state then to a wife?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Nay, all the freedom that a virgin hath
Is much to be preferred. Who would endure
The humours of so insolent a thing
As is a husband? Which of all the herd
Runs not possessed with some notorious vice,
Drinking or whoring, fighting, jealousy,
Even of a page at twelve, or of a groom,
That rubs horse-heels? Is it not daily seen,
Men take wives, but to dress their meat, to wash
And starch their linen: for the other matter
Of lying with them, that's but when they please:
And whatsoever the joy be of the bed,
The pangs that follow procreation
Are hideous, or you wives have gulled your husbands
With your loud shrikings, and your deathful throes.
A wife or widow to a virgin's life?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.l: Why should the best of you think ye enjoy
The rest and rule, that a free widow doth?
I am mine own commander, and the bliss
Of wooers, and of each variety
Frequents me, as I were a maid. No brother
Have I to dice my patrimony away, as you
My maiden madam may. No husband's death
Stand I in doubt on: for thanks be to heaven
(If mine were good) the grievous loss of him
Is not to come; if he were bad, he's gone,
And I no more embrace my injury.
But be yours ill, you nightly clasp your hate;
Or good, why he may die, or change his virtue.
And thou (Though single) haste a bedfellow
As bad as the worst husband, thought of one,
And what that is, men with their wives do do,
And long expectance till the deed be done.
"A wife is like a garment used and torn:
" a maid like one made up, but never worn.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: "A widow is a garment worn threadbare,
Selling at second hand, like broker's ware.
But let us speak of things the present time
Make happy to us, and see what is best.
I have a servant than the crown of men,
The fountain of humanity, the prize
Of every virtue, moral and divine;
Young, valiant, learned, well-born, rich and shaped
As if wise nature when she fashioned him,
Had meant to give him nothing but his form,
Yet all additions are conferred on him,
That may delight a woman: this same youth
To me hath sacrificed his heart, yet I
Have checked his suit, laughed at his worthy service,
Made him the exercise of my cruelty,
Whilst constant as the sun, for all these clouds
His love goes on.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.l: Peace, here's the man you name.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Widow. We'll stand aside.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Good morrow to the glory of our age.
The lady perfect, and the lady bright,
The virtuous wife and widow: but to you
The lady honour, and my mistress,
The happiness of your witness.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: By this light, I never heard one speak so scuruily,
Utter such stale wit, and pronounce so ill.
But to you,
My lady honour, and my mistress,
The happiness of your wishes.

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.l: Stop your wit,
You would fain show these ladies what a hand
You hold over your servant. It shall not need,
I will express your tyranny well enough.
I have loved this lady since I was a child,
Since I could construe Am●: now she says
I do not love her, 'cause I do not weep,
lay mine arms o'er my heart, and wear no garters,
Walk with mine eyes in my hat, sigh, and make faces
For all the poets in the town to laugh at,
Pox a this howling love, 'tis like a dog
Shut out midnight. Must love needs be powdered,
Lie steeped in brine; or will it not keep sweet?
Is it like beef in summer?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Did you ever
Hear one talk fustian like a butcher thus?

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.l: 'Tis foolish, this same telling folks we love,
It needs no words, to will show itself in deeds,
And did I take you for an entertainer,
A lady that will wring one by the finger,
Whilst on another's toes she treads, and cries
By gad I love but one, and you are he:
Either of them thinking himself the man,
I'd tell you in your ear, put for the business,
Which granted, or denied, madam God bye.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Come these are daily slanders that you raise,
On our infirm and unresisting sex,
You never me● I am sure with such a lady.

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.l: O many by this light, I have seen a chamber
Frequented like an office of the law,
Clients succeed at midnight one another:
Whilst the poor madam filth been so distressed,
Which of her loves to show most 〈…〉
That his dull husband has perceived her wiles.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Nay perhaps taught her, many of those husbands
Are base enough
To live upon't.

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.l: I have seen another of 'em
Cheat by this light at cards, and set her women,
To talk to the gentlemen that played,
That so distracted they might over see.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: O fie upon ye, I dare swear you lie.

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.l: Do not fair mistress, you will be for sworn.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: You men are all soul mouthed, I warrant, you
talk thus of me and other ladies here,
Because we keep the city.

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.l: O profane.
That thought would damn me, will you marry yet?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: No I will never marry.

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.l: Shall we then
Couple unlawfully? for indeed this marrying
Is but proclaiming what we mean to do;
Which may be done privately, in civil sort
And none the wiser, and by this white hand la:
The wrack, strappado, or the boiling boot,
Should never force me tell to wrong your honour.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: May I believe this?

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.l: Let it be your creed.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: But if you should prove false. Nay ne'er unhang
Your sword, except you mean to hang yourself:
Why where have you been drinking? 'sfoot you talk
Like one of these same rambling boys,
That reign in Turnbull-street.

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.l: How do you know?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Indeed my knowledge, is but speculative
Not practic there, I have it by relation,
From such observers as yourself dear servant,
I must profess, I did think well of thee,
But get thee from my sight, I never more
Will hear or see thee, but will hate thee deadly,
As a man enemy, or a woman turned.
Ladies come forth, see sir what courtesy
You have done to me, a strange praise of you
Had newly left my lips, just, as you entered,
And how you have deserved it, with your carriage?
Villain, thou hast hurt mine honour to these friends,
For what can they imagine but some ill ▪
Hath passed betwixt us by thy broad discourse?
Were my case theirs, by virgin chastity,
I should condemn them: hence, depart my sight.

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.l: Madam, but hear me, o that these were men,
and durst but say or think you ill, for this
I have so good a cause upon my side.
That I would cut their hearts out of their breasts:
And the thoughts out of them that injured you.
But I obey your best, and for my penance,
Will run a course never to see you more,
And now I lose you, may I lose the light:
Since in that beauty dwelled my day or night.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Is this the virtuous youth?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Your happiness?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Wherein you thought your seat so far 'bove ours,

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: If one man could be good, this had been he.
See here comes all your suitors, and your husband,
And room for laughter, here's the lord feesimple,
What gentlewoman does he bring along?

div.stage: Enter husband, embracing Subtle, the lord Fee-simple, with young Bould like a waiting gentlewoman ▪ well-tried, husb: Subtle talk with wife.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p: One and thirty good-morrows to the fairest, wisest, chastest, richest widow that ever conversation coped withal.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Three score and two unto the wisest lord,
That ever was trained in university.

sp.speaker: Feesimp.
sp.p: O courteous, bounteous widow, she has outbid me 31. Good morrows at a clap.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: But my lord feesimple you forgotten the business imposed on you.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p:
Gentlewoman, I cry thee mercy, but 'tis a fault in all lords, not in me only, we do use to swear by our honours: and as we are noble, to dispatch such a business for such a gentleman and we are bound, even by the same honours we sware by, to forget it in a quarter of an hour.
And look as if we had never seen the party, when we meet next, especially if none of our gentlemen have been considered.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Ay, but all yours have, for you keep none my lord: besides though it stands with your honour to forget men's businesses; yet it stands not with your honour, if you do not do a woman's.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Why then madam, so it is that I request your ladyship to accept into your service this gentlewoman, for her truth and honesty I will be bound, I have known her too long to be deceived, this is the second time I have seen her.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Why how now my lord: a preferrer of gentlewomen to service like an old knitting woman? where hath she dwelled before.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: She dwelled with young Bould's sister, he that is my corrival in your love, she requested me to advance her to you; for you are a dubbed lady: so is not she yet.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: But now you talk of young bold, when did you see him lady?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Not this month master Well-tried.
I did conjure him to forbear my sight:
Indeed swore if he came I'd be denied.
sp.p: But 'tis strange you should ask for him, ye two were wont never to be asunder.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Faith madam we never were together but we differed on some argument or other,
sp.l: And doubting lest our discord might at length
Breed to some quarrel, I forbear him to.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p: He quarrel? Bold: hang him, if he durst have quarrelled, the world knows he's within a mile of an oak has put him to't, and soundly, I never cared for him in my life, but to see his sister, he's an ass, pox an arrant ass, for do you think any but an arrant ass, would offer to come a-wooing , where a lord atempts? he quarrel: he dares not quarrel.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.l: But he dares fight my lord, upon my knowledge,
And rail no more my lord, behind his back,
for if you do my lord blood must ensue.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.l: O, o my honour dies, I am dead.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.l: Ud'slight what's the matter, wring him by the nose

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: A pair of riding spurs now were worth gold,

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Pins are as good, prick him, prick him

sp.speaker: Feesim.
sp.l: O, o.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: He's come again, lift him up.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: How fares your lordship?

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p: O friends, you have wronged my spirit to call 〈◊〉 back, I was e'en in Elysium at rest.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: But why sir did you swoon?

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Well though I die master Well-tried before all these I do forgive you, because you were ignorant of my infirmity, o sir, is't not up yet, I die again, put up now whilst I wink, or I do wink for ever.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: 'Tis up my lord, open your eyes, but I pray tell me is this antipathy twixt bright steel and you natural, or how grew it?

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: I'll tell you sir, any thing bright and edged, works thus strongly with me, your hilts now I can handle as boldly, look you else.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.p: Nay never blame my lord master Well-tried, for I know a great many will swoon at the sight of a shoulder of mutton or a quarter of lamb, my lord may be excused then, for a naked sword.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: This lord, and this knight in dog-collars would make a fine brace of beagles.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: But on my faith 'twas mightily overseen of your father, not to bring you up to foils, or if he had bound you prentice to a cutler or an ironmonger.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p: I a pox, hang him old gouty fool, he never brought me up to any lordly exercise, as fencing, dancing, rumbling, and such like: but forsooth I must write and read, and speak languages, and such base qualities, fit for none but gentlemen. Now sir would I tell him, father you are a count, I am a lo: a pox a writing and reading, and languages, let me be brought up as I was born.

sp.speaker: Subtle.
sp.p: But how my lord came you first not to endure the sight of steel.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Why I'll tell you sir, when I was a child, an infant, an innocent.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Was e'en now.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p: I being in the kitchen, in my lo: my father's house, the cook was making minced pies: so sir, I standing by the dresser, there lay a heap of plums. Here was he mincing; what did me I sir, being a notable little witty coxcomb, but popped my hand just under his chopping knife, to snatch some raisins, and so was cut o'er the hand, and never since could I endure the sight of any edge-tool.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Indeed they are not fit for you my lord, and now you are all so well satisfied in this matter, pray ladies how like you this my gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: In troth madam exceeding well I, if you be provided, pray let me have her.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: It should be my request, but that I am full.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: What can you do? What's her name my lord?

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p: Her name? I know not. What's her name Mr. Well-tried?

sp.speaker: Weltr.
sp.p: Her name? slid, tell my lady your name.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Mistress Mary princox forsooth.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Mistress Mary Princax: she has wit, I perceive that already. Methinks she speaks as if she were a my lord's brood.

sp.speaker: Bould
sp.p: Brood madam, 'tis well known I am a gentlewoman. My father was a man of 500. per annum, and he held something in capite too.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: So does my lord, something.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p: Nay, by my troth, what I hold in capite is worth little or nothing.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
I have had apt breeding, however my misfortune now makes me submit myself to service: but there is no ebb so low, but hath his tide again: when our days are at worst, they will mend in spite of the frowning destinies. For we cannot be lower than earth, and the same
blind dame that hath cast her blear eyes hitherto upon my occasions, may turn her wheel, and at last wind them up with her white hand to some pinnacle that prosperously may flourish in the sunshine of promotion.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p: O mouth, full of agility, I would give 20. Marks now to any person that could teach me to convey my tongue (Sans stumbling) with such dexterity to such a period. For her truth and her honesty I am bound before, but now I have heard her talk, for her wit I will be bound body and goods.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Ud'slight, I will not leave her for my hood. I never met with one of these eloquent old gentlewomen before. What age are you mistress Mary princox?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: I will not lie madam, I have numbered 57. Summers, and just so many winters have I passed.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: But they have not passed you, they lie frozen in your face.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Madam, if it shall please you to entertain me, so: if not, I desire you not to misconstrue my good will, there's no harm done, the door's as big as it was, and your ladyships own wishes crown your beauty with content. As for these frumping gallants, let them do their worst: it is not in man's power to hurt me: 'tis well known I come not to be scoffed. A woman may bear and bear till her back burst. I am a poor gentlewoman, and since virtue has nowadays no other companion but poverty, I set the hare's head against the goose giblets, and what I want one way I hope I shall be enabled to supply the other.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p: An't please God, that thou wert not passed children;

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Is't e'en so my lord? nay good princox do not cry, I do entertain you, how do you occupy? what can you use?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Any thing fit to be put into the hands of a gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: What are your qualities?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
I can sleep on a low stool, if your ladyship be talking in the same room with any gentleman, I can read
on a book, sing love songs, look up at the louvre light, hear and be deaf, see and be blind, be ever dumb to your secrets, swear and equivocate, and whatsoever I spy, say the best.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: O rare crone? how art thou endued? but why did master Bould's sister put you away?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: I beseech you madam to neglect that desire, though I know your Ladyship's understanding to be sufficient to partake or take in the greatest secret; can be imparted: yet. —

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Nay prithee tell the cause, come here's none but friends.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Faith madam, heigh ho, I was (To confess truly) a little foolish in my last service, to believe men's oaths, but I hope my example, though prejudicial to myself, will be beneficial to other young gentlewomen in service, my mistress's brother (The gentleman you named e'en now, master bold) having often attempted my honour, but finding it impregnable, vowed love, and marriage to me, at the last I, a young thing and raw, being seduced, set my mind upon him, but friends contradicting the match, I fell into a grievous consumption, and upon my first recovery, lest the intended sacred ceremonies of nuptials should succeed, his sister knowing this, thought it fit in her judgement, we should be farther asunder, and so put me out of her service.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: God a mercy for this discovery i'faith,
O man what art thou? when thy cock is up? come will your lordship walk in? 'tis dinner time.

div.stage: Enter hastily m. Seldom with papers on his arm.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Who's this? who's this?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: This is our landlord, master seldom,
An exceeding wise citizen, a very sufficient understanding man, and exceeding rich.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Miracles are not ceased.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Good morrow landlord, where have you been sweating?

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.p:
Good morrow to your honours, thrift is industrious, your ladyship knows we will not stick to sweat for our
pleasures, how much more ought we to sweat for our profits? I am come from master Ingen this morning, who is married or to be married, and though your ladyships did not honour his nuptials with your presence, he hath by me sent each of you a pair of gloves, and grace seldom my wife is not forgotten.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: God give him joy, God give him joy.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Let all things most impossible change now.
O perjured man! oaths are but words I see.
But wherefore should not we that think we love
Upon full merit, that same worth once ceasing
Surcease our love to, and find new desert?
Alas we cannot, love's a pit, which, when
We fall into we never get out again,
And this same horrid news which me assaults
I would forget, love blanches blackest faults:
Oh! what path shall I tread for remedy?
But darkest shades, where love with death doth lie.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sir I have often heard my husband speak of your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Nay my virtuous wife,
Had it been but acquaintance, this his absence
Had not appeared so uncouth, but we two
Were schoolfellows together, born and nursed,
Brought up, and lived since like the Gemins,
Had but one suck, the tavern or the ordinary.
Ere I was married, that saw one of us
Without the other, said we walked by halves,
Where dear, dear friend have you been all this while?

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: O most sweet friend the world's so vicious,
That had I with such familiarity
Frequented you since you were married,
Possessed and used your fortunes as before,
As in like manner you commanded mine,
The depraved thoughts of men would have proclaimed
Some scandalous rumours from this love of ours,
as saying, mine reflected on your lady,
And what a wound had that been to our souls?
When only friendship should have been the ground
To hurt her honour, and your confident peace,
Spite of mine own approved integrity.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Wife, kiss him, bid him welcome pox o'th world,
Come, come you shall not part from me in haste,
I do command thee use this gentleman
In all things like myself, if I should die
I would be him in my will to thee.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sir, you are most welcome, and let scandalous tongues
No more deter you, I dare use you sir,
With all the right belonging to a friend,
And what I dare, I dare let all man see
My conscience rather, than men's thoughts be free.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Will you look in?
We'll follow you. Now friend
What think you of this lady?

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: Why sweet friend,
That you are happy in her, she is fair,
Witty and virtuous, and was rich to you,
Can there be an addition to a wife?

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Yes, constancy, for 'tis not chastity
That lives remote from all attempers free,
But there, 'tis strong and pure where all that woo
It doth resist, and turns them virtuous too;
Therefore dear friend, by this, loves masculine kiss,
By all our mutual engagements passed,
By all the hopes of amity to come,
Be you the settler of my jealous thoughts,
And make me kill my fond suspect of her,
By assurance that she is loyal, otherwise
That she is false, and then, as she's passed cure,
My soul shall ever after be passed care.
That you are fittest for this enterprise
You must needs understand, since prove she true
(In this your trial) you my dearest friend,
(Whom only, rather than the world besides
I would have satisfied of her virtue) shall be,
And best conceal my folly, prove she weak,
'Tis better you should know't than any man,
Who can reform her, and do me no wrong,
Chemical metals, and bright gold itself
By sight are not distinguished, but by'th test,
Thought makes good wives, but trial makes the best:
To the unskilful owner's eyes, alike
The Bristol sparkles as the diamond,
But by a lapidary the truth is found,
Come you shall not deny me.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: Do not wrong
So fair a wife (Friend) and so virtuous,
Whose good name is a theme unto the world,
Make not a wound with searching where was none,
Misfortune still such projects doth pursue,
He makes a false wife, that suspects a true;
Yet since you so importune, give me leave
To ruminate a while, and I will straight
Follow and give you an answer.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: You must do it.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: Assure yourself dear — coxcomb, I will do't
Or strangely be denied, all's as I wished,
This was my aim, although I have seemed strange.
I know this fellow now to be an ass;
A most unworthy husband though in view
He bear himself thus fair, she knows this too,
Therefore the stronger are my hopes to gain her:
And my dear friend that will have your wife tried,
I'll try her first, then thrust her if I can,
And as you said most wisely I hoped to be
Both touchstone to your wise and lapidary.

div.head: Actus secundi scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Seldom his wife working as in their shop.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Husband these gloves are not fit for my wearing, I'll put 'em into the shop and sell 'em, you shall give me a plain pair for them.

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.p: This is wonderful, wonderful, this is thy sweet care and judgement in all things, this goodness is not usual in our wives, well grace seldom, that thou art fair is nothing, that thou art well spoken is nothing, that thou art witty is nothing, that thou art a citizen's wife is nothing; but grace, that thou art fair, that thou art well spoken, that thou art witty, that thou art a citizen's wife, and that thou art honest I say, and let any must deny it that can, it is something, it is something, I say, it is Seldome's something, and for all the sunshine of my joy mine eyes must rain upon thee.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: By your leave master seldom, have you done the hangers I bespoke for the knight?

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.p: Yes marry have I mistress hic et hac, I'll fetch 'em to you.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: Zounds, does not your husband know my name, if it had been somebody else I would have called him cuckoldly slave.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: If it had been somebody else perhaps you might.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: Well I may be even with him, all's clear; pretty rogue I have longed to know thee this twelve months, and had no other means but this to speak with thee, there's a letter to thee from the party.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.l: What party?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: The knight sir John Lovall.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.l: Hence lewd impudent
I know not what to term thee man or woman,
For nature shaming to acknowledge thee
For either; hath produced thee to the world
Without a sex, some say thou art a woman,
Others a man; and many thou art both
Woman and man, but I think rather neither
Or man and horse, as the old centaurs were feigned.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: Why how now mistress, what lack ye? are you so so fine with a pox? I have seen a woman look as modestly as you, and speak as sincerely, and follow the friars as zealously, and she has been as sound a jumbler as e'er paid for't, 'tis true mrs. Fipeny, I have sworn to leave this letter.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.l: D'ye hear, you sword and target (To speak in
Your own key) Marry Umbree, Long-meg,
Thou that in thyself ( methink'st ) alone
Lookest like a rogue and a whore under a hedge:
Bawd, take your letter with you and begone,
When next you come (My husband's constable)
And Bridewell is hard by, you've a good wit,
And can conceive.

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.l: Look you, here are the hangers.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Let's see them.
Fie, fie, you have mistook me quite,
They are not for my turn (B'y mistress seldom)

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.l: Here's my lord proudly.

sp.speaker: Lo. Proud.
sp.l: My horse lackey, is my sister honour above?

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.p: I think her ladyship, my lord, is not well, and keeps her chamber.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: All's one, I must see her, have the other la. dined?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I think not my lord.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: Then I'll take a pipe of tobacco here in your shop if it be not offensive, I would be loath to be thought to come just at dinner time. Garsoon; fill, sirrah,Enter page with a pipe of tobacco.what said the goldsmith for the money?

div.stage: Seldom having fetch a candle, walks off at th' other end of the shop, lord sits by his wife.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: He said my lord he would lend no man money that he durst not arrest.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: How got that wit into Cheapside 'tro, he is a cuckold.
Saw you my lady today, what says she?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Marry my lord, she said her old husband had a great payment to make this morning, and had not left her so much as a jewel.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: A pox of her old cat's chops, the teeth she had, have made a transmigration into hair, she hath a bigger beard than I by this light.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: This custom in us citizens is good,
Thus walking off when men talk with our wives,
It shows us courteous, and mannerly,
Some count it baseness, he's a fool that does so,
It is the highest point of policy
Especially when we have virtuous wives.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.l: Fie, fie, you talk uncivilly my lord.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Uncivilly, mew, can a lord talk uncivilly? I think you a finical taffatae pipkin may be proud I'll sit so near it, uncivilly mew.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Your mother's cat has kittened in your mouth sure:

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Prithee but note yo● fellow, does he not walk and look as if he did desire to be a cuckold?

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: But you do not look as if you could make him one, now they have dined my lord.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: God save your lordship.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: How dost thou coz, hast thou got any more wit yet?

sp.speaker: Feesim.
sp.p: No by my troth I have but little money with that little wit I have, and the more wit ever the less money, yet as little as I have of either: I would give some thing that I durst but quarrel,
I would not be abused thus daily as I am.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Save you my lord.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Good master Well-tried, you can inform me, pray how ended the quarrel betwixt young bold, and the other gentleman.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.l: Why very fairly my lord, on honourable terms,
Young bold was injured and did challenge him,
Fought in the field, and the other gave him satisfaction
Under his hand, I was Bould's second, and can show it here.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: 'Tis strange there was no hurt done, yet I hold the other gentleman, far the better man.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: So do not I.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Besides they say the satisfaction that walks in the ordinaries, is counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.l: He lies that says so, and I'll make it good,
And for I know my friend is out of town,
what man soever wrongs him is my foe,
I say he had full satisfaction,
Nay that which we may call submission:
That the other sought peace first, and who denies this,
Lord, knight, or gentleman, English, French, or scot,
I'll fight and prove it on him with my sword.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: No sweet master Well-tried, let's have no fighting till (As you have promised) you have rid me from this foolish fear, and taught me to endure to look upon a naked sword.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Well and I'll be as good as my word.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: But do you hear cousin proudly? they say my old father must marry your sister honour, and that he will disinherit me, and entail all his lordships on her, and the heir he shall beget on her body, is't true or not?

sp.speaker: Proudly.
sp.l: There is such a report.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.l: Why then I pray God he may die an old cuckoldly
Slave, o world what art thou? where is parents' love?
Can he deny me for his natural child,
Yet see (O fornicator) old and stiff,
Not where he should be, that's my comfort yet,
sp.p: As for you my lord: I will send to you as soon as I dare fight and look upon steel, which master Well-tried I pray let be with all possible speed.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: What d'ye this afternoon.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Faith I have a great mind to see long-megg and the ship at the fortune.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Nay i'faith let's up and have a rest at primero.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Agreed my lord, and towards the evening I'll carry you to the company.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Well no more words.

div.stage: Exeunt lord provdly, lord fees. Wel-tr.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I wonder sir you will walk so and let anybody sit prating to your wife! were I a man I'd thrust 'em out o'th' shop by the head and shoulders.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: There were no policy in that wife, so should I lose their custom, let them talk themselves weary, and give thee love tokens still, I lose not by it.
sp.l: Thy chastity's impregnable, I know it,
Had I a dame whose eyes did swallow youth,
Whose unchaste gulf together did take in
Masters, and men, the foot-bodies and their lords, making a gallimaufry in her blood,
I would not walk thus then: but virtuous wife,
He that in chaste ears poors his ribald talk
Begets hate to himself, and not consent;
And even as dirt thrown hard against a wall
Rebounds and sparkles in the throwers eyes,
So ill words uttered to a virtuous dame,
Turn and defile the speaker with red shame.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Zounds, you are a whore, though I entreat him fair
Before his face, in compliment, or so,
I not esteem him truly as this rush,
There's no such thing as friendship in the world,
And he that can not swear, dissemble, lie,
Wants knowledge how to live, and let him die.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sir I did think you had esteemed of him
As you made show, therefore I used him well,
And yet not so but that the strictest eye
I durst have made a witness of my carriage.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Plague a your carriage, why he kissed your hand,
Looked babies in your eyes, and wink't and pinked,
You thought I had esteemed him, 'sblood you whore,
Do not I know, that you do know you lie,
When didst thou hear me say and mean one thing?
O I could kick you now, and tear your face
And eat thy breasts like udders.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sir you may, but if I know what hath deserved all this I am no woman, 'cause he kissed my hand, unwillingly.

sp.speaker: Hurb.
sp.l: A little louder pray.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You are a base fellow, an unworthy man
As e'er poor gentlewoman matched withal,
Why should you make such show of love to any
Without the truth, thy beastly mind is like
Some decayed tradesman that doth make his wife
entertain those for gain he not endures,
Pish, swell and burst, I had rather with thy sword
Be hewed to pieces, then lead such a life,
Out with it valiant sir, I hold you for
A drawer upon women, not on men,
I will no more conceal your hollow heart,
But e'en report you as you are in truth.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: This is called marriage, stop your mouth you whore.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Thy mother was a whore if I be one.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: You know there's company in the house, sweet friend
What have you writ your letter?

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: 'Tis done, dear friend, I have made you stay too long
I fear you'll be benighted.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Fie, no, no,
Madam and sweetest wife farewell, God bless us,
Make much of master subtle here my friend
Till my return, which may be e'en as't happens,
According as my business hath success.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: How will you pass the time, now fairest mistress.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: In troth I know not, wives without their husbands
Methinks are lowering days.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: Indeed some wives
Are like dead bodies in their husband's absence.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: If any wife be, I must needs be so
That have a husband far above all men,
Untainted with the humour's others have,
A perfect man, and one that loves you truly,
You see the charge he left of your good usage.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: Push, he's an ass, I know him, a stark ass.
Of a most barbarous condition,
False-hearted to his friend, rough unto you,
A most dissembling and perfidious fellow,
I care not if he heard me, this I know,
And will make good upon him with my sword
Or any for him, for he will not fight.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Fie servant, you show small civility
And less humanity, d'ye require
my husband's love thus ill, or what ●●ee think
Of me, that you will utter to my face
Such harsh, unfriendly, slanderous injuries
Even of my husband? Sir, forbear I pray
My ears, or your own tongue, I am no housewife
To hear my husband's merit thus depraved.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: His merit is a halter by this light,
You think he's out of town now, no such matter
But gone aside, and hath importuned me
To try your chastity.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: It cannot be,
Alas he is as free from jealousy,
And ever was as confidence itself,
I know he loves me to, too heartily
To be suspicious, or to prove my truth.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: If I do feign in ought, never may I purchase
The grace I hope for, and fair mistress
If you have any spirit or wit, or sense,
You will be even with such a wretched slave,
Heaven knows I love you, as the air I draw,
Think but how finely you may cuckold him,
And safely too, with me, who will report
To him, that you are most invincible,
Your chastity not to be subdued by man.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: When you know, I'm a whore.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: A whore, fie, no,
That you have been kind, or so, your whore doth live
In Pickt-hatch, Turnebole-streete.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Your whore lives there,
Well servant leave me to myself a while,
Return a none, but bear this hope away,
'Tshall be with you, if I at all do stray.
Why here's right worldly friendship, ye are well met;
O men! what are you? why is our poor sex
Still made the disgrac't subjects, in these plays?
For vices, folly, and inconstancy?
When were men looked into with such critical eyes
Of observation, many would be found
So full of gross and base corruption,
that none (Unless the devil himself turned writer)
Could feign so badly, to express them truly;
Some wives that had a husband now like mine,
Would yield their honours up, to any man,
Far be it from my thoughts, o let me stand,
Thou god of marriage and chastity,
An honour to my sex, no injury,
Compel the virtue of my breast to yield,
It's not revenge for any wife, to stain
The nuptial bed, although she be yoked ill,
Who falls, because her husband so hath done,
Cures not his wound, but in herself makes one.

div.stage: Enter Ingen reading a letter, sits down in a chair and stamps with his foot: to him a servant.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Who brought this letter?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: A little Irish footboy, sir, he stays without for an answer.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Bid him come in lord.
What deep dissemblers are these females, all,
How far unlike a friend, this lady used me,
And here, how like one mad in love, she writes:
sp.stage: Enter maid like an Irish footboy with a dart, and gloves in her pocket, and a handkercher.
sp.l: So bless me heaven, but thou art the prettiest boy
That e'er ran by a horse, hast thou dwelled long
With thy fair mistress?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: I came but this morning, sir.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: How fares thy lady, boy?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Like to a turtle, that hath lost her mate,
Drooping she sits, her grief sir cannot speak,
Had it a voice articulate, we should know
How, and for what she suffers; and perhaps,
(But 'tis unlikely) give her comfort sir,
Weeping she sits, and all the sound comes from her,
Is like the murmur of a silver brook,
Which her tears truly, would make there about her,
sat she in any hollow continent.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Believe me boy ▪ thou hast a passionate tongue,
Lively expression, or thy memory
Hath carried thy lesson well away,
But wherefore mourns thy lady?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Sir, you know,
And would to God I did not know myself.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Ah 'las, it cannot be for love to me,
When last I saw her she reviled me (Boy)
With bitterest words, and wished me never more
To approach her sight, and for my marriage, now
I do sustain it, as a penance, due
To the desert, that made her banish me.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Sir, I dare swear, she did presume, no words
Nor dangers, had been powerful to restrain
Your coming to her, when she gave the charge —
But are you married truly?

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Why my boy?
Dost think I mock myself, I sent her gloves.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: The gloves she has returned you sir by me,
And prays you give them to some other lady
That you'll deceive next, and be perjured to.
Sure you have wronged her sir, she bade me tell you,
She never thought goodness dwelled in many men,
But what there was of goodness in the world,
She thought you had it all, but now she sees
The jewel she esteemed is counterfeit
That, you are but a common man, yourself,
A traitor to her, and her virtuous love;
That all men are betrayers and their breasts
As full of dangerous gulfs, as is the sea,
Where any woman thinking to find harbor,
She and her honour are precipitated,
And never to be brought with safety off:
Alas my hapless lady, desolate,
Distressed, forsaken virgin.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Sure this boy
Is of an excellent nature, who so newly
ta'en to her service, feels his mistress grief,
As he and they were old familiar friends,
Why weepest thou gentle lord?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Who hath one tear,
And would not save't from all occasions,
From brother's slaughters, and from mother's deaths
To spend it here, for my distressed lady;
But sir my lady did command me beg
To see your wife, that I may bear to her
The sad report, what creature could make you
Untie the hand-fast plighted unto her.

div.stage: Enter his brother like a woman masked. Ingen kisses her.

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.l: Wife, wife, come forth now— gentle boy, be judge
If such a face as this being paid with scorn
By her I did adore, had not full power
To make me marry.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: By the god of love,
She's a fair creature, but faith should be fairer.
My lady, gentle mistress, one that thought
She had some interest in this gentleman,
(Who now is only yours) commanded me
To kiss your white hand, and to sigh and weep,
And wish you that content she should have had
In the fruition of her love you hold,
She bad me say, God give you joy, to both;
Yet this withal (If ye were married)
No one, her footsteps ever more should meet,
Nor see her face, but in a winding sheet.

sp.speaker: Brother.
sp.l: Alas poor lady, 'faith I pity her,
And, but to be i'th same state, could forgo
Any thing I possess, to ease her woe.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Love's blessing light upon thy gentle soul,
Men rail at women mistress, bu●t is we
Are false and cruel, ten times more unkind,
You are smoother far, and of a softer mind:
Sir, I have one request more.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Gentle lad, it must be one of a strange-quality
That I deny thee, both thy form, and mind.
Inform me that thy nurture hath been better,
Than to betray thee to this present life.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: 'Tis, that you would vouchsafe to entertain me,
My feet do tremble under me, to bear
My body back unto my uncouth lady,
To assure her grief; what heart so hard, would owe
A tongue, to tell so sad a tale to her?
Alas, I dare not look upon her eyes,
Where wronged love, sits like the basilisk,
And sure would kill me for my dire report,
Or rather should not I appear like death,
When every word I speak shot through her heart,
More mortally than his unsparing dart.

sp.speaker: Brother.
sp.l: Let me speak for the boy.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: To what end (Love)
No, I will sue to him, to follow me,
Introth I love thy sweet condition,
And may live to inform thy lady of thee;
Come in dry, dry thine eyes, respite thy woe:
The effects of causes, crown, or overthrow.

div.stage: Enter Lo. Provd. Lo. Feesim. Wel-tri'd, ma. Seldom, widd. Bould pin in a ruff, wife.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: 'Slight, what should be become of her, you swear she passed not forth of doors, and i'th house she is not?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Did you not see her princox?

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: This same bawd has brought her letters from some younger brother, and she is stole away.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Bawd, I defy you, indeed your lordship thinks, you may make bawds of whom you please, I'll take my oath upon a book, since I met her in the necessary house i'th morning, I never set eye on her.

sp.speaker: Grace
sp.p: She went not out of doors.

sp.speaker: Proud
sp.p: Sure she has an invisible ring.

sp.speaker: Feesi
sp.p:
Marry she's the honester woman, for some of their ring are visible enough, the more shame for them, still say I, let the pond at Islington be searched: go to, there's more
have drowned themselves for love this year than you are aware of.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: Pish, you are a fool.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: S'hart call him fool again.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: By this light and I will, as soon as ever you have showed me the swaggerers.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Her clothes are all yonder my lord.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: And even those same she had on today.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: Madam where is your husband?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Rid into the country.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: On my conscience, rid into France with your sister.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Away, away for shame.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Why, I hope she is not the first lady that has run away with other women's husbands.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: It may be she's stolen out to see a play.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: Who should go with her, man?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Upon my life you'll hear on her at master ingens house, some love passed betwixt them, and we heard that he was married today, to another.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: S'hart, I'll go see.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Come to the swaggerers.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Mercy upon me, a man or a — lord now?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Here's a quoil, with a lord and his sister.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Princox, hast not thou pined in that ruff yet, ah! how thou fumblest.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Troth madam, I was never brought up to it, 'tis chambermaid's work, and I have ever lived gentlewoman. And been used accordingly.

div.head: Actus tertius.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: She's a rare wife believe it sir, were all such,
We never should have false inheritors.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Pish friend, there is no woman in the world
Can hold out in the end, if youth, shape, wit,
Met in one subject, do assault her aptly,
for failing once, you must not faint but try
Another way, the path of women's minds
Are crooked, and divers, they have byways
To lead you to the palace of their pleasures,
And you must woo discreetly; first observe
The disposition of her you attempt,
If she be sprightly, and heroical,
Possess her that you are valiant, and have spirit,
Talk nothing but of beating every man
That is your hindrance, though you do not do it,
Or dare not, 'tis no matter. Be she free
And of a liberal soul, give bounteously
To all the servants, let your angels fly
About the room, although you borrowed 'em.
If she be witty, so must your discourse
Get wit, what shift soe'er you make for it,
Though't cost you all your land, and then a song
Or two is not amiss, although you buy 'em,
There's many in the town will furnish you.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: But still I tell you, you must use her roughly,
Beat her face black and blue, take all her clothes
And give them to some punk, this will be ground
For me to work upon.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: All this I have done.
I 〈…〉 her now, as bare, that should I die,
Her fortune (O my conscience) would be
To marry some tobacco-man, she has nothing
But an old black-work waistcoat, which would serve
Exceeding well to fit i'th shop and light
Pipes for the lousy footmen (And sweet friend)
First here's a jewel to present her, then
Here is a sonnet writ against myself,
Which as thine own thou shalt accost her with,
Farewell and happy success attend thee.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.
Faire'd, still wilt thou be true
To a man so false to thee?
Did be le●d a husband's due,
thou didst owe him loyalty;
But will curses, wants and blows
Breed no change in thy white soul▪
Be not a fool to thy first vows,
Since his breach, doth thy faith control,
No beauty else, could be so chaste,
Think not thou honour'st women then,
Since by thy conscience, all disgraced,
Are robbed of the dear loves of men;
Then grant me my desire that vow to prove
A real husband, his adulterate love.
Took ever man more pains to be a cuckold?
Oh! monstrous age where men themselves we see,
Study and pay for their own infamy.

div.stage: Enter Ingen, maid, provdly, brother like a woman, swords drawn.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.l: Give me my sister, I'll have her forth thy heart.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: No earthly lord can pull her out of that,
Till he have plucked my heart first out, my lord
Were't not inhospitable, I could wrong you here
In mine own house ▪ I am so full of woe,
For your lost sister that by all my joys
Hop't for in her, my heart weeps tears of blood,
A whiter virgin, and a worthier,
Had never creation: Leda's swan was black
To her virginity, and immaculate thoughts.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.l: Where hast thou hid her? give her me again,
For by the god of vengeance, be she lost,
The female hate shall spring betwixt our names,
Shall never die, while one of either house
Survives, our children shall at seven years old
Strike knives in one another.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Let hell gape
And take me quick, if I know where she is,
But am so charged with sorrow for her loss,
Being one cause of it (As no doubt I am)
That I had rather fall upon my sword
Then breathe a minute longer.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: O sir! hold.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.l: Thou shalt not need, I have a sword to bathe
In thy false blood, inhumane murderer.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Good sir be pacified, I'll go, I'll run
Many a mile to find your sister out;
She never was so desperate of grace,
By violence to rob herself of life,
And so her soul in danger; comfort sir,
She's but retired somewhere on my life.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Prithee let me alone —
Do I stand to defend that wretched life
That is in doubt of hers, here worthy lord,
Behold a breast, framed of thy sister's love,
Hew it, for thou shalt strike but on a stock,
Since she is gone that was the cause it lived.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.l: Out false dissembler, are not married?

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: No, behold, it is my younger brother dressed,
A man, no woman, that hath gulled the world,
Intended for a happier event
Than this that followed, that she now is gone,
O fond experiments of simple man,
Fool to thy fate, since all thy project meant
But mirth, is now converted unto death.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: O do not burst me joy, that modesty
Would let me show myself to finish all.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.l: Nay, then thou hast my sister somewhere villain,
'Tis plain now, thou wilt steal thy marriage,
She is no match for thee, assure thyself.
If all the law in England, or my friends
Can cross it, 'tshall not be.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Would 'twere so well,
And that I knew the lady to be safe.
Give me no ill words; sir, this boy and I
Will wander like to pilgrims, till we find her:
If you do love her as you talk, do so:
The love or grief that is expressed in words,
Is sleight and easy, 'tis but shallow woe
That makes a noise, deep'st water's stillest go;
I love her better than thy parents did,
which is beyond a brother.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.l: Slave, thou liest.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Zounds.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: Kill him.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: O hold; sir, you dishonour much your brother,
To counsel him 'gainst hospitality,
To strike in his own house.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: You, lord insolent, I will fight with you,
Take this, as a challenge, and set your time.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.l: Tomorrow morning Ingen,
'Tis that I covet, and provoke thee for.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: Will you not strike him now?

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: No, my good boy
Is both discreet and just in his advice,
Thy glories are to last but for a day;
Give me thy hand, tomorrow morning thou shalt be no lo.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.l: Tomorrow noon, thou shalt not be at all.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Pish, why should you think so, have not I arms ▪
A soul as bold as yours, a sword as true:
I do not think your honour in the field
Without your lordship's liveries will have odds.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Farewell, and let's have no excuses, pray.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: I warrant you, pray say your prayers tonight ,
And bring no inkhorn w●ee, to set your hand to
A satisfactory recantation.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: O wretched maid, whose sword can I pray for?
But by the others loss, I must find death,
O odious brother, if he kill my love,
O bloody love, if he should kill my brother;
Despair on both sides of my discontent,
Tells me no safety rests but to prevent.

div.stage: Enter widow and Bould like princox.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: What's o'clock princox?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.l: Bedtime an't please you madam.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Come, undress me, would God had made me a man.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.l: Why, madam?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Because I would have been in bed as soon as they, we are so long unpinning and unlacing.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p:
Yet many of us madam are quickly undone sometime, but herein we have the advantage of men, though 〈◊〉
they can be a-bed sooner than we, it's a great while when they are a-bed ere they can get up.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Indeed if they be well laid princox, one cannot get them up again in haste.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: O God madam, how mean you that, I hope you know, ill things taken into a gentlewoman's ears, are the quick corrupters of maiden modesty, I would be loath to continue in any service unfit for my virgin estate, or where the world should take any notice of light behaviour in the lady I follow: for madam, the main point of chastity in a lady, is to build the rock of a good opinion amongst the people by circumstances, and a fair show she must make, si, non cast, tamen caste madame, and though wit be a wanton madam: yet I beseech your ladyship for your own credit and mine, let the bridle of judgement be always in the chaps of it to give it head, or restrain it, according as time and place shall be convenient.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Precise and learned princox, dost not thou go to Blackfriars.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Most frequently madam, unworthy vessel that I am to partake or retain any of the delicious dew, that is there distilled.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: But why shouldst thou ask me what I meant e'en now, I tell thee there's nothing uttered that carries a double sense, one good, one bad, but if the hearer apply it to the worst, the fault lies in his or her corrupt understanding, not in the speaker, for to answer your latin: pravis omnia prava, believe me wench, if ill come into my fancy, I will purge it by speech ▪ the less will remain within: a pox of these nice mouthed creatures, I have seen a narrow pair of lips utter as broad a tail, as can be bought for money; indeed an ill tale unuttered, is like a maggot in a nut, it spoils the whitest kernel.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: You speak most intelligently madam.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Hast not done yet? thou art an old fumbler, I perceive methinks thou dost not do things like a woman.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
Madam, I do my endeavour, and the best can do no more, they that could do better, it may be would
not, and then 'twere all one, but rather than be a burden to your ladyship, I protest sincerely, I would beg my bread, therefore I beseech you madam to hold me excused, and let my good will stand for the action.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Let thy good will stand for the action? If good will would do it, there's many a lady in this land would be content with her old lord, and thou canst not be a burden to me, without thou lie upon me, and that were preposterous in thy sex; take no exceptions at what I say, remember you said stand even-now, there was a word for one of your coat indeed.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: I sweat madam, you are very merry, God send you good luck, has your ladyship no waters, that you use at bedtime?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: No introth, princox.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: No complexion?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: None but mine own I swear, didst thou ever use any?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: No indeed madam: now and then a piece of scarlet, or so; a little white and red ceruse; but in troth madam, I have an excellent receipt for a night mask, as ever you heard.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Boar's grease one ounce, Jordan almonds blanched and ground a quartern, red rose-water, half a pint, mare's urine, newly covered, half a score drops.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Fough, no more of thy medicine, if thou lovest me, few of our knights errant, when they meet a fair lady errant, in a morning, would think her face had lain so plastered all night: thou hast had some apothecary to thy sweet heart: but leaving this face physic, for (By my troth) it may make others have good ones; but it makes me make a scurvy one. Which of all the gallants in the town wouldst thou make a husband of, if thou mightst have him for thy choosing?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: In troth madam, i but you'll say I speak blindly, but let my love stand aside .

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: I think it not fit indeed your love should stand in the middle.

sp.speaker: Boul.
sp.p:
I say master bold; o, do but mark him madam,
his leg, his hand, his body, and all his members stand in print.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Out upon thee princox; no, methinks Well-tried a handsome fellow, I like not these starched gallants: masculine faces, and masculine gestures please me best.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: How like you master p●rt?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: ●ie upon him, when he is in his scarlet clothes, he looks like man of wax, and I had as leave have a dog a wax, I do not think but he lies in a case a nights, he walks as if he were made of gyves, as if nature had wrought him in a frame, I have seen him sit discontented a whole play, because one of the purls of his band was fallen (Out of his reach) to order again.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Why? Bold madam is clean contrary.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: I but that's as ill, each extreme, is a like vicious; his careful carelessness is his study, he spends as much time to make himself slovenly, as the other to be spruce, his garters hang ever on the calves of his legs, his doublet unbuttoned, and his points untrust, his hair in's eyes like a drunkard, and his hat worn on his hinder part of his head, as if he cared more for his memory, than his wit: makes him look as if he were distracted; princox, I would have you lie with me, I do not love to lie alone.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: With all my heart madam.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Are you clean skinned?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Clean skinned madam▪ there's a question, do you think I have the itch? I am an englishwoman, I protest, I scorn the motion.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Nay prithee princox be not angry, it's a sign of honesty I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Faith madam I think 'tis but simple honesty that dwells at the sign of me scab.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Well, well, come to bed, and we'll talk further of all these matters.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.l: Fortune, I thank thee, I will owe thee eyes
For this good turn, now is she mine indeed,
Thou hast given me that success my project hoped
Of, false disguise that hast been true to me,
And now be bold, that thou may'st welcome be.

div.stage: Enter whore-bang, bots, teare-chops, spill-blood, and drawer: several patches on their faces.

sp.speaker: Tear.
sp.p: Dam-me, we will have more wine, sirrah, or we'll down into the seller, and drown thee in a butt of malmsey, and he wall the hogsheads in pieces.

sp.speaker: Whoore.
sp.p: Hang him rogue, shall he die as honourably as the Duke of Clarence; by this flesh let's have wine, or I will cut thy head off, have it roasted and eaten in pie-corner next Bartholmew-tide.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Gentlemen, I beseech you consider where you are, Turne-bole's street, a civil place, do not disturb a number a poor gentlewomen, master Whore-bang, Ms: bots, ma: Teare-chops, and ma: Spillblood the watch are abroad.

sp.speaker: Spilb.
sp.p: The watch? why you rogue, are not we Kings of Turne-bole's?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Yes marry are ye, sir, for my part, if you'll be quiet, I'll have a sign made of ye, and it shall be called the four Kings of Turnbole .

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Will you fetch us wine?

sp.speaker: Whoore.
sp.p: And a whore (Sirrah)

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Why what d'ye think of me, am I an infidel, a Turk, a pagan, a Sarazen, I have been at Bess Turnip's, and she swears all the gentlewomen went to see a play at the fortune, and are not come in yet, and she believes they sup with the players.

sp.speaker: Tear.
sp.p: Damn, we must kill all those rogues, we shall never keep a whore honest for them.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Go your ways, sirrah, we'll have but a gallon a piece, and an ounce of tobacco.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: I beseech you, let it be but pottles.

sp.speaker: Spilb.
sp.p: S'hart you rogue?

sp.speaker: Whoore.
sp.p: Master Well-tried, welcome as my soul.

div.stage: Enter drawer with wine, plate, and tobacco.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Noble lad, how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Spilb.
sp.p: As welcome, as the tobacco and the wine boy.

sp.speaker: Tear.
sp.p: Damn thou art.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p: Bless me (Save you gent) they have not one face among 'em. I could wish myself well from them, I would I had put out something upon my return, I had as leave be at the barmuthoes.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Pray welcome this gentleman.

sp.speaker: Spilb.
sp.p: Is he valiant?

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Faith he's a little faulty that way: somewhat of a bashful and backward nature, yet I have brought him amongst you, because he hath a great desire to be fleshed.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p: Yes faith sir, I have a great desire to be fleshed: now Mr. Well-tried said, he would bring me to the only flesh-mongers in the town.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Sir, he cannot endure the sight of steel.

sp.speaker: Whor.
sp.p: Not steel? zounds.

div.stage: Claps his sword o'er the table.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p: Now I am going.

sp.speaker: Bot.
sp.p: Here's to you sir, I'll fetch you again with a cup of sack.

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p: I pledge you sir, and begin to you in a cup of claret:

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Hark you my lo: what will you say, if I make you beat all these out of the room?

sp.speaker: Fees.
sp.p: What will I say? why I say it is impossible, 'tis not is mortal man.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Well drink apace, if any brave you out brave him, I'll second you, they are a company of cowards believe me.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: By this light I would they were else, if I thought so, I would be upon the jack of one of 'em instantly, that same little dame me, but Mr. Well-tried if they be not very valiant or dare not fight! how come they by such cuts and gashes, and such broken faces?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why their whores strike 'em with cans, and glasses, and quart pots, if they have nothing by 'em, they strike 'em with the pox, and you know that will lay ones nose as flat as a basket hilt dagger.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: Well let me alone.

sp.speaker: Tear.
sp.p: This bully dares not drink.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: Dare I not sir.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Well said, speak to him man.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: You had best try me sir.

sp.speaker: Spilb.
sp.p: We four will drink four healths to four of the seven deadly sins, pride, drunkenness, wrath and lechery.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: I'll pledge 'em, and I thank you, I know 'em all, here's one.

sp.speaker: Wh
sp.p: Which of the sins?

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: By my troth e'en to pride.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why well said, and in this do not you only pledge your mistress health, but all the women's in the world.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: So now, this little cup to wrath, because he and I are strangers.

sp.speaker: Tear.
sp.p: Brave boy, dame me he shall be a roarer.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: Damn me, I will be a roarer, or't shall cost me a fall.

sp.speaker: Botts.
sp.p: The next place that falls, pray let him have it.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: Well, I have two of my healths to drink yet, lechery and drunkenness which e'en shall go together.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Why how now my lord, a moralist?

sp.speaker: Botts.
sp.p: Damn me, art thou a lo: what virtues hast thou?

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: Vertues? enough to keep ere a dame me company in England, methinks you should think it virtue enough to be a lord.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Will not you pledge these healths? we'll have no observers.

sp.speaker: Welt
sp.p: Why, mounser whore-bang? I am no play maker, and for pledging your healths, I love none of the four, you drank to so well.

sp.speaker: Spilb.
sp.p: Zounds you shall pledge me this.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Shall I?

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: What's the matter, dost hear master Well-tried, use thine own discretion, if thou wilt not pledge him, say so? and let me see, if ere a dame me of 'em all, will force thee.

sp.speaker: Spilb.
sp.p: Puff, will your lordship take any tobacco? you lord with the white face?

sp.speaker: Botts.
sp.p: Heart he cannot put it through his nose.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: Faith you have ne'er a nose to put it through, d'ye heart blow your face sirrah.

sp.speaker: Tear.
sp.p: You'll pledge me sir?

sp.speaker: Wilt.
sp.p: Indeed I will not.

sp.speaker: Tear.
sp.p: Damn me he shall not then.

sp.speaker: Tear.
sp.l: Lord, use your own words, dame me is mine,
I am known by it all the town o'er, d'ye hear?

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: It is as free for me as you, d'ye hear patch?

sp.speaker: Tear.
sp.p: I have paid more for't.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Nay I'll bear him witness in a truth, his soul lies fort my lord.

sp.speaker: Spilb.
sp.p:
Well-tried, you are grown proud since you got
good clothes, and have followed your lord.

sp.speaker: Whoore.
sp.p: I have known you lousy, well tried,

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Rorer you lie.

div.stage: Draw and fight, throw pot● and stools.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: O Jesu.

sp.speaker: All Sw.
sp.p: Zounds cleave or be cleft: pell-mell , slash arms and legs.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: Heart let me alone with 'em.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Why now thou art a worthy wight, indeed a lord a lorne.

sp.speaker: Fee
sp.p: I am a mad man, look is not that one of their heads?

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Fie no my lord.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: Damn me but 'tis, I would not wish you to cross me a purpose, if you have any thing to say to me, so, I am ready.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: O brave lord, many a roarer thus is made by wine: come it is one of their heads my lord.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.p: Why so then, I will have my humour, if you love me, let's go break windows somewhere.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Drawer, take your plate, for the reckoning there's some of their cloaks: I will be no shot-log to such.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: God's blessing o'your heart, for thus ridding the house of them.

div.head: Actus quarti scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter widow undressed, a sword in her hand, and Bould in his sh●●t, as started from bed.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Uncivil man, if I should take thy I ●e,
It were not to be weighed with thy attempt:
Thou hast for ever lost me.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.l: Madam ▪ why?
Can love beget loss? Do I covet you
Unlawfully? Am I an unfit man.
To make an husband of? Send for a priest,
First consummate the match, and then to bed
Without more trouble.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: No, I will not do't.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.l: Why you confessed to me as you're gentlewoman,
I was the man your heart did most affect:
That you did dote upon my mind and body.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: So, by the sacred and inviolate knot
Of marriage, I do, but will not wed thee.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.l: Why yet enjoy me now. Consider lady,
That little, but blessed time, I was in bed,
Although I lay as by my sister's side,
The world is apt to censure otherwise:
So 'tis necessity that we marry now.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Pish, I regard not (At a straw) the world:
Fame from the tongues of men doth injury
Oftener than justice ▪ and as conscience
Only makes guilty persons, not report:
(For show we clear as springs unto the world,
If our own knowledge do not make us so,
That is no satisfaction to ourselves ▪)
So stand we never so leprous to men's eye,
It cannot hurt heart-known integrity.
You have trusted to that fond opinion,
This is the way to have a widowhood,
By getting to her bed: alas young man,
Shouldst thou thyself tell thy companions
Thou hadst dishonoured me (As you men have tongues
Forked and venomed 'gainst our subject sex)
It should not move me, that know 'tis not so:
Therefore depart, truth be my virtuous shield.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.l: Few widows would do thus.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: All modest, would.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.l: To be in bed and in possession
Even of the mark I aimed at, and go off
Foiled and disgraced, come, come, you'll laugh at me
Behind my back, publish I wanted spirit,
And mock me to the ladies, call me child,
Say you denied me but to try the heat
And zeal of my affection towards you,
Then clapped up with a rime, as for example.
He coldly loves, retires, for one vain trial,
For we are yielding, when we make denial.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Servant I make no question, from this time
You'll hold a more reverent opinion
of some that wear long coats, and 'tis my pride,
To assure you that there are amongst us good:
And with this continency, if you go away,
I'll be so far from thinking it defect,
That I will hold you worthiest of men.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.l: S'hart, I am Tantalus, my longed for fruit
Bobs at my lips, yet still it shrinks from me.
Have not I that, which men say never fails
To o'ercome any? opportunity?
Come, come, I am too cold in my assault.
By all the virtues, that yet ever were
In man, or woman, I with reverence
Do love thee lady, but will be no fool
To let occasion slip, her foretop from me.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: You will fail this way to, upon my knees
I do desire thee to preserve thy virtues,
And with my tears my honour; 'tis as bad
To lose our worths to them, or to deceive
Who have held worthy opinions of us,
As to betray trust: all this I implore
For thine own sake, not mine, as for myself,
If thou beest violent, by this stupid night,
And all the mischiefs her dark womb hath bred,
I'll raise the house, I'll cry a rape.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I hope you will not hang me, that were murder lady,
A greater sin, then lying with me sure.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Come, flatter not yourself with argument,
I will exclaim; the law hangs you, not I,
Or if I did, I had rather far confound
The dearest body in the world to me,
Then that, that body, should confound my soul.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.l: Your soul, alas mistress, are you so fond
To think her general destruction
Can be procured by such a natural act,
Which beasts are born to and have privilege in?
Fie, fie, if this could be, far happier
Are sensitive souls in their creation
Than man the prince of creatures, think you heaven
regards such mortal deeds, or punisheth
Those acts, for which he hath ordained us?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: You argue like an atheist, man is never
The prince of creatures, as you call him now,
But in his reason, fail that, he is worse
Than horse or dog, or beasts of wilderness,
And 'tis that reason teacheth us to do
Our actions unlike them: then that which you
Termed in them a privilege beyond us,
The baseness of their being doth express,
Compared to ours, horses, bulls, and swine,
Do leap their dams, because man does not so,
Shall we conclude his making happiless?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.l: You put me down, yet will not put me down,
I am too gentle, some of you I have heard,
Love not these words but force, to have it done
As they sing pricksong, e'en at the first sight.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Go too, keep off, by heaven and earth, I'll call else.

sp.speaker: Bould
sp.l: How if nobody hear you?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: If they do not,
I'll kill you with mine own hand, never stare,
Or failing that fall on this sword myself.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.l: O widow wonderful, if thou beest not honest.
Now God forgive my mother and my sisters.
Think but how finely madam undiscovered
For ever you and I, might live all day your gentlewoman
To do you service, but all night your man
To do you service, newness of the trick,
If nothing else might stir ye.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: 'Tis a stale one
And was done in the fleet ten years ago,
Will you begone? the door is open for you.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.l: Let me but tarry till the morning madam,
To send for clothes, shall I go naked home.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: 'Tis best time now, it is but one o'clock ,
And you may go unseen, I swear by heaven,
I would spend all the night to sit and talk w'ee,
If I durst trust you, I do love you so,
my blood forsakes my heart now you depart.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.l: S'hart, will you marry me hereafter then?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: No, you are too young, and I am much too old;
I and unworthy, and the world will say,
We married not for love, good morrow servant.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Why so? these women are the arrant'st jugglers in the world, the wry-legged fellow is an ass to 'em. Well IMusic.must have this widow, whate'er come on't: faith she has turned me out of her service very barely, hark, what's here, music.

div.stage: Enter Subtle with a paper, and his boy with a cloak.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: Rise lady mistress, rise:
The night hath tedious been,
No sleep hath fallen into my eyes,
Nor slumbers made me sin.
Is not she a saint then say,
Thought of whom keeps sin away?
Rise madam, rise and give me light,
Whom darkness still will cover.
And ignorance darker than night,
Till thou smile on thy lover;
All want day 〈◊〉 thy beauty rise,
For the grate morn breaks from thine eyes.
Now sing it sirrah.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, who's this? young master bold? God save you, you are an early stirrer.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: You say true master subtle, I have been early up, but as God help me, I was never the near.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Where have you been sir?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: What's that to you sir? at a woman's labour.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Very good: I near took you for a man midwife before.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: The troth is, I have been up all night at dice, and lost my clothes, good morrow master subtle, pray God the watch be broke up: I thank you for my music:

sp.speaker: Subt:
sp.p:
'Tis palpable by this air, her husband and being abroad, bold has lain with her, and is now conveyed out of doors. Is this the lady perfect with a pox? The truth is, her virtuous
chastity, began to make me make a miracle of her, still holding out to me, notwithstanding her husband's most barbarous usage of her, but now indeed 'tis no marvel since another possesses her. Well madam, I'll go find out your cuckold, I'll be revenged on you and tell a tale shall tickle him, this is a cheat in love, not to be born, another to beguile me of the game, I played for all this while.

div.stage: Enter Weltri'd, and Bould putting on his doublet, Fee-simple on a bed, as in Bould's chamber.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: You see, we made bold with your lodging, indeed, I did assure myself, you were fast for this night.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: But how the devil came this fool in your company?

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: 'Sfoot man, I carried him last night among the roarers, to flesh him, and by this light he got drunk, and beat 'em all.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Why then he can endure the sight of a drawn sword now?

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: O God sir, I think in my conscience, he will eat steel shortly, I know not how his conversion will hold after this sleep, but in an hour or two (Last night) he was grown such a little damn-me, that I protest, I was afraid of the spirit, that I myself had raised in him: but this other matter of your expulsion thus mads me to the heart; were you in bed with her?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: In bed by heaven.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: I'll be hanged, if you were not busy to soon, you should have let her slept first.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Zounds man, she put her hands to my breasts and swore I was no maid, now I being eager to prove her words true, took that hint, and would violently have thrust her hand lower, when her thought being swifter than my strength, made her no sooner imagine that she was betrayed, but she leaps out of the bed, whips me down a sword that hung by, and as, if fortitude and justice had met to assist her, spite of all argument fair or foul she forced me away.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p:
But is't possible thou shouldst have no more wit, wouldst thou come away upon any terms, but sure ones,
having night, her chamber and herself naked in thine arms? By that light, if I had a son of ●4 whom I had help 't thus far, that had served me so, I would breech him.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: S'hart, what would you have me done?

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Have done? done, done twice at least.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Have played Tarquin and ravished her.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Pish, Tarquin was a blockhead, if he had had any wit and could have spoke, Lucrece had never been ravished, she would have yielded, I warrant thee, and so will any woman

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: I was such an erroneous heretic to love, and women, as thou art, till now.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: God's precious, it makes me mad, when I think on't: was there ever such an absurd trick? now will she abuse thee horribly, say thou art a faint-hearted fellow, a milksop and I know not what, as indeed thou art.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Zounds, would you had been in my place.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Zounds, I would I had, I would have so jumbled her honesty: wouldst thou be held out at staff's end with words? dost not thou know a widow's a weak vessel, and is easily cast if you close.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Well-tried, you deal unfriendly.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: By this light I shall blush to be seen in thy company.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Pray leave my chamber.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.l: Pox upon your chamber,
I care not for your chamber, nor yourself
More than you care for me.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: 'Sblood I as little for you.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.l: Why fare you well.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Why, farewell you. Well-tried, I prithee stay,
Thou knowest I love thee.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: S'hart, I love you as well; but for my spleen, or choler I think, I have as much as you.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Well friend, this is the business you must do for me,
Repair unto the widow, where give out,
Tomorrow morn, I shall be married,
Invite her to the wedding, I have a trick,
