To put upon this lord to, whom I made
My instrument to prefer me.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.l: What shall follow,
I will not ask, because I mean to see't.
The ●ars 'twixt friends, still keeps their friendship sweet.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.l: Why Well-tried, you rogue, what's that a vision?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Why how now my lord? who do you call rogue? the gentleman you name is my friend, if you were wise I should be angry.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.l: Angry with me? why dam me sir, and you be;
Cut with your sword, it is not with me I tell you
As it was yesterday, I am flesh man, I.
Have you any thing to say to me?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Nothing but this, how many do you think, you have slain last night?

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Why five, I never kill less.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: There was but four: my lord, you had best provide yourself and begone, three you have slain stark dead.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: You jest.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: 'Tis most true, Well-tried is fled.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Why let the roarers meddle with me another time, as for flying, I scorn it, I killed 'em like a man; when did you ever see a lord hang for any thing? we may kill whom we list, marry my conscience pricks me; ah plague a this drink, what things it makes us do, I do no more remember this now than a puppy-dog.
sp.l: O bloody lord that art bedaubed with gore,
Vain world adieu, for I will roar no more.

sp.speaker: Bould
sp.p: Nay stay my lord, I did but try the tenderness of your conscience, all this is nothing so, but to sweeten the tale (I have for you) I foretold you this feigned mischance.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Is it a tale belonging to the widow?

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: I think you are a witch.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: My grandmother was suspected.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: The widow has desired you by me to meet her tomorrow morning at church in some unknown disguise, lest any suspect it, for quoth she,
sp.l: Long hath he held me fast in his moist hand,
Therefore I will be his in nuptial band.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p:
Bold, I have ever taken you to be my friend, I am very wise now, and valiant, if this be not true, damn-me sir,
you are the son of a whore, and you lie, and I will make it good with my sword.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: I am, whate'er you please sir, if it be not true, I will go with you to the church myself, your disguise I have thought on; the widow is your own. Come, leave your fooling.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.l: If this be true, thou little boy,

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.l: So true, as thou tell'st to me,
Tomorrow morn when I have the widow,
My dear friend shalt thou be.

div.stage: Enter maid like the footboy: Seldom with a couple of serieants, pits, donner.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis most true and in this shall you be
Unlike to other citizens that arrest
To undo gentlemen: your clemency here
Perchance saves two lives, one from the others sword,
The other from the laws; this morn they fight,
And though your debtor be a lord, yet should he
Miscarry, certainly your debt were lost.

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.l: Dost thou serve the lord proudly?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Sir, I do.

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.l: Well, such a boy as thou, is worth more money
Than thy lord owes me, 'tis not for the debt
I do arrest him, but to end this strife,
Which both may lose my money and his life.

div.stage: Enter lord provdly with a riding rod.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: My horse there, zounds I would not for the world
He should alight before me in the field,
My name and honor were for ever lost.

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.l: Good morrow to your honour, I do hear
Your lordship this fair morning is to fight,
And for your honour: did you never see
The play, where the fat knight hight Oldcastle,
Did tell you truly what this honour was?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Why, how now good man flatcap, what d'ye lack?
Who do you talk to, sirrah?

sp.speaker: 1. Serg.
sp.l: We arrest you.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Arrest me, rogue? I am a lord ye curs, a parliament man.

sp.speaker: 2. Serg.
sp.l: Sir, we arrest you though.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: At whose suit?

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.l: At mine, sir.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Why thou base rogue, did not I set thee up,
Having no stock, but thy fair shop and wise?

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.l: Into my house with him.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Away with him, away with him.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: A plot, a trick by heaven. See ingens footboy, 'tis by his master's means, o coward, slave; I'll put in bail, or pay the debt.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Ay, ay, ay, we'll talk with you within — thrust him in.

div.stage: Enter Ingen looking on his sword and bending it, his brother like a man.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: If I miscarry frank, I prithee see
All my debts paid, about five hundred pounds
Will fully satisfy all men, and my land
And what I else possess, by nature's right
And thy descent, Frank, I make freely thine.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: I know, you do not think I wish you dead
For all the benefit: besides, your spirit
So opposite to counsel, to avert
Your resolution, that I save my breath,
Which would be lost in vain, to expire and spend
Upon your foe, if you fall under him.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Frank, I protest you shall do injury
Unto my foe, and much disturbance to
Unto my soul departing, die I here
Fairly, and on my single enemy's sword,
If you should not let him go off untouched.
Now by the master of thy life and mine,
I love thee boy, beyond any example,
As well as thou dost me, but should I go
Thy second to the field, as thou dost mine,
And if thine enemy killed thee like a man,
I would desire, never to see him more,
But he should bear himself off with those wounds
He had received from thee, for that time safe,
And without persecution by the law,
For what hap is our foes, might be our own,
And no man's judgement, sits in justice place,
but weighing other men's as his own case.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: He has the advantage of you being a lord,
For should you kill him, you are sure to die,
And by some lawyer with a golden tongue,
That cries for right, ten angels on his side;
Your daring meet him, called presumption:
But kill he you, he, and his noble friends
Have such a golden snaffle for the jaws
Of man, devouring Pithagorean law,
They'll rein her stubborn chaps, e'en to her tail?
And though she have iron teeth to meaner men,
So master her, that who displeased her most,
She shall lie under like a tired jade,
For small boats on rough seas are quickly lost,
But ships ride safe, and cut what by they list.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Follow what may, I am resolved dear brother,
This monster valour, that doth feed on men,
Groans in me for my reputation.
This charge I give thee to, if I do die,
Never to part from the young boy, which late
I entertained, but love him for my sake:
And for my mistress the lady honour,
Whom to deceive, I have deceived myself.
If she be dead, pray God I may give up
My life a sacrifice on her, brother's sword;
But if thou liv'st to see her gentle brother,
If I be slain, tell her I died because
I had transgressed against her worthy love.
This sword is not well mounted, let's see thine.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Your staying sir, is in vain, for my lord proudly,
Just at his taking horse to meet you here,
At Seldome's suit the citizen, was arrested
Upon an action of two hundred pounds,
I saw it sir, 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: O, scurvy lord,
It had been a cleanlier shift than this to have had
It hindered by command, he being a lord,
but I will find him.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.l: You see, valiant sir, I have got loose
For all your stratagem, o rogue are you there.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Most ignoble lord.

div.stage: Ingen stabs Proud. in the left arm.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.l: Coward thou didst this
That I might be disabled for the fight,
Or that thou mightst have some excuse to shun me,
But 'tis my left arm, thou hast lighted on.
I have no second; here are three of you,
If all do murder me, your consciences
Will more than hang you, damn you; come prepare.

sp.speaker: In.
sp.l: Brother walk off, and take the boy away, is he hurt much?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: Nothing or very little.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p: I'll bind your wound up first, your loss of blood may sooner make you faint.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Ingen, thou art a worthy gentleman, for this courtesy,
Go-to I'll save thy life, come on sir: hay,
I'll cut your codpiece point sir, with this thrust,
And then down goes your breeches.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Your lordship's merry
I had like to have spoilt your cutwork band.

div.stage: Enter maid like a footboy running, brother after him, maid kneels betwixt 'em.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: O master, hold your hand, my lord hold yours,
Or let your swords meet in this wretched breast,
Yet you are both well, what blood you have lost
Give it as for the injury you did, and now be friends,

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: S'hart, 'tis a loving rogue.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Kind boy, stand up, 'tis for thy wound he bleeds,
My wrong is yet unsatisfied.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Hence away it is a sister's loss, that whets my sword.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: O stay, my lord, behold your sister here
Bleeding by your hand servant see your mistress
Turned to thy servant running by thy horse,
Whose means it was to have prevented this, but all in vain.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: O noble lady.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Most worthy pattern of all women kind.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.l: Ingen, I am satisfied, put up your sword.
Sister, you must with me, I have a husband
The lord Fee-simple's father, old, but rich:
This gentleman is no match for you; kneel not,
That portion of yours, I have consumed,
Thus marrying, you shall never come to want.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: O I s●eet my lord, my brother do not force me,
To break my faith or to a loathed bed.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Force you, he shall not, brother bear her hence,
She is my wife, and thou shalt find my cause
Ten times improved now.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: O, have at you sir.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Hold, hold for heaven's sake, was e'er wretched lady
Put to this hazard? Sir, let me speak
But one word with him, and I'll go with you,
And undergo, whatever you command.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.l: Do't quickly, for I love no whispering,
'Tis strange to see you madam with a sword,
You should have come hither in your lady's clothes.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Well, as you please my lord, you are witness, whatsoever before
sp.l: Hath passed betwixt us: thus I do undo.
Were not I mad to think thou couldst love me
That wouldst have slain my brother?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Sayest true sister.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p: O thou fair creature! wilt thou be as false as other ladies?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Thou art my example,
I'll kiss thee once, farewell for ever, come my lord, now
Match me, with whom you please, a tumbler.
I must do this, else had they fought again.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Mine own best sister, farewell Mr. Ingen.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: O ancient truth to be denied of no man,
An eel by'th tail's held surer than a woman.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: She is not to be cast.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: It cannot be: had you a wife, and I were in your
Case.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: I would be hanged even at the chamber door
Where I attempted, but I'll lay her flat.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: Why tell me truly, would it please you best,
To have her remain chaste, or conquered.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: O friend it would do me good at the heart
To have her over come, she does so brag
And stand upon her chastity forsooth.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: Why then in plain terms sir, the fort is mine,
Your wife has yielded, up-tails is her song,
The deed is done, come, now, be merry man.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Is the deed done indeed? come, come, you jest,
Has my wife yielded? is uptailes her song?
Faith come, in prose, how got you to the matter first, ha.
Pish, you are so bashful now.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Why, by my troth I'll tell you, because you are my friend, otherwise you must note it is a great hurt to the art of whore-mastery to discover, besides the skill was never mine o'th price.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Very good, on sir.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: At the first she was horrible stiff against me, than
Sir I took her by the hand, which I kissed.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: And I called her pretty rogue, and I thrust my finger betwixt her breasts, and I made lips; at last, I pulled her by the chin to me, and I kissed her.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.p: Hum, very good.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: So at the first, she kissed very strangely, close, and untoward; then said I to her, think but upon the wrongs, the intolerable wrongs, the rogue your husband does you.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.p: I that was very good, what said she to you then sir?

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Nay, I went on. First quoth I, think how he hath used you, left you no means, given all your clothes to his punks, struck you, turned your grey eyes into black ones, but yet —

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.p: A pretty conceit.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p: Quoth I, these things are nothing in the rascal, think but what a base whoremaster, the rascal is.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.p: Did you call me rascal so often are you sure.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.p:
Yes, and oftener, for said I, none comes amiss to
the rogue, I have known him quoth I, do three lousy beggars under hedges in the riding of ten mile, and I swore this to.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.p: 'Twas very well, but you did lie. On I pray.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p: Pish, one must lie a little, now sir by this time she began to kiss some what more openly, and familiarly, her resistance began to slacken, and my assault began to stiffen, the more her bulwark decayed, the more my battery fortified, at last sir, a little fumbling being passed to make the conquest more difficult, she perceiving my readiness mounted, falls me flat upon her back, cries me out aloud
sp.l: Alas I yield, use me not roughly friend,
My fort, that like Troy town, ten years hath stood
Besieged and shot at did remain unwon:
But now 'tis conquered. So the deed was done▪

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Then came the hottest service. Forward with your tale sir.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Nay caetera, quis neset, lassi requienimus ambo ▪
Proveniant medii sic mihi sape dies.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.p: Which is as much to say: I am a cuckold, in all languages, but sure 'tis not so, it is impossible my wife should yield.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.p: Heyday, e'en now, it was impossible she should hold out, and now it is impossible she should yield, stay you but here and be an ear witness to what follows, I'll fetch your wife. I know he will not stay.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.p: Good faith sir but he will. I do suspect some knavery in this.
sp.l: Here will I hide myself, when thought as gone,
If they do ought unfitting I will call
Witness, and straight way sue a divorce.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: I knew he would not ●●ay. Now noble mistress,
I claim your promise.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What was that good seruan

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: That you would lie with me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: If with any man,
But prithee first consider with thyself
If I should yield to thee, what a load thy conscience
would bear about it, for I wish quick thunder
May strike me, if I yet have lost the truth,
Or whiteness of the hand I gave in church,
And 'twill not be, thy happiness (As thou thinkst)
That thou alone shouldst make a woman fall,
That did resist all else, but to thy soul
A bitter corrosive, that thou didst stain,
Virtue that else had stood immaculate,
Nor speak I this, as yielding unto thee,
For 'tis not in thy power, wert thou the sweetest
Of nature's children, and the happiest,
To conquer me, nor in mine own to yield,
And thus it is with every pious wife.
Thy daily railing at my absent husband
Makes me endure thee worse, for let him do
The most preposterous ill relishing things
To me, they seem good, since my husband does 'em,
Nor am I to revenge or govern him,
And thus it should be with all virtuous wives.

sp.speaker: Sub.
sp.l: Pox a this virtue and this chastity,
Do you know fair mistress, a young gentleman
About this town called bold, where did he lie
Last night, sweet mistress, o o, are you catched,
I saw him slip out of the house this morn,
As naked as this truth, and for this cause
I have told your husband that you yielded to me,
And he I warrant you, will blaze it thoroughly,
As good do now then as be thought to do.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: No, 'twill not be yet, thou injurious man,
How wilt thou right me in my husband's thoughts,
That on a false surmise, and spite haste told,
A tale to breed uncurable discontent?
Bold was that old wench that did serve the widow,
And thinking by this way to gain her love
Missed of his purpose, and was thus cashiered,
Nor cares she to proclaim it to the world.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Zounds, I have wronged you mistress. On my knees
I ask you pardon, and will never more,
attempt your purity, but neglect all things
Till that soul wrong I have bred in your knight
I have expelled, and let your loves aright.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Which now is done already madam wife,
Upon my knees, with weeping eyes, heaved hands,
I ask thy pardon, o sweet virtuous creature,
I prithee break my head.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Rise, rise, sir pray ▪
You have done no wrong to me, at least I think so;
Heaven hath prevented all my injury,
I do forgive and marry you a new.
Come, we are all invited to the weddings,
The lady honour to the old rich count.
Young bold unto another gentlewoman,
We and the widow are invited thither,
Embrace and love, henceforth more really,
Not so like worldlings.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Here then ends all strife
Thus false friends are made true, by a true wife.

div.head: Actus quinti scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter old count wrapped in furs, the lady honour dressed like a bride, the lord Provd. Wel-tri'd, Bould, leading Fee-simple like a lady masqued, husband, wife, Subtle with a letter, widow, to them brother, Seldom, and his wife.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: Health and all joy unto this fair assembly,
My brother, who last tide is gone for France,
A branch of willow feathering his hat,
Bade me salute you lady, and present you
With this same letter written in his blood,
He prays no man, for his sake evermore
To credit woman, nor no lady ever
To believe man, so either sex shall rest
Uninjured by the other, this is all, and this I have delivered.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I and well, you pronounce rarely did you never play?

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: Yes, that I have, the fool, as some lords do.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.l: Set forward there.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: O, o, o, a pox a this cold.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.l: A cold a this pox you might say, I am a feared.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: How full of ghastly wounds this letter shows, o, o.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Look to my sister.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: S'hart the lady swoons.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Strong-water there.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.l: If strong breath would recover her, I am for her.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: Alas good lady, hum, hum, hum. coughs perpetually

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: He has fetched her again with coughing.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Convey me to my bed send for a priest
And a physician, your bride I fear,
In stead of epithalamions shall need
A dirge, or epitaph, o lead me in,
My body dies for my soul's perjured sin.

div.stage: Exit maid, grace, wife, Husb. subtle.

sp.speaker: Bould
sp.l: Hymen comes towards us in a mourning robe.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.l: I hope friend, we shall have the better day.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.l: I'll fetch the parson and physician

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: They are both ready for you.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.l: Madam, this is the gentlewoman.
Who something bashful does desire your pardon, that she
Does not unmask.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Good master Well-tried, I would not buy her face, and for her manners if they were worse, they shall not displease me.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: I thank your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Look, how the old ass my father stands, he looks like the bear in the play, he has killed the lady with his very sight as God help me, I have the most to do to forbear unmasquing me, that I might tell him his own, as can be.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.l: Fie, by no means.
The widow comes towards you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: O, o, o, o.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Servant, God give you joy, and gentlewoman,
Or lady as full joy, I wish to you,
Nor doubt that I will hinder you, your love,
But here am come to do all courtesy
To your fair self, and husband that shall be.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.l: I thank you heartily.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.l: S'hart, speak smaller man.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.l: I thank you heartily.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: You're going to this gear to Mr. bold, umh, umh, umh.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p: Not to your couching gear my lord, though I be not so old, or rich as your lordship, yet I love a young wench as well.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: As well, as my lord, nay by my faith, that you do not, love a young wench as well as he, I wonder you will be unmannerly to say so.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Faith master Well-tried, troth is I love them well, but they love not me, umh, umh, umh, you see, what ill luck, I have with them, ump, ump, ump, a pox a this cold still say I.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Where got you this cold my lord? it can get in nowhere that I can see, but at your nostrils, or eyes, all the other parts are so barricadoed with fur.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: It got in at his eyes, and made that birdlime there where Cupid's wings do hang entangled.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Is this your wife, that (Umh, umh, umh) shall be, ma. Bold, I'll be so bold as kiss her.

div.stage: Count. sits in a chair and falls asleep .

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Sir, forbear, I have one bold enough to kiss my 〈◊〉, o old coxcomb, kiss thine own natural son, 'tis worse than a justice's lying with his own daughter, but Mr. Well-tried when will the widow break this matter to me?

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Not till the very close of all, she dissembles it yet, because my Lo●● your father is here, and her other suitor bold.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.l: That's all one, he's o'th plot a my side:

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: 'Tis needless master bold, but I will do
Any thing you require to satisfy you,
Why should you doubt, I will forbid the banes,
For so your friend, here told me? I should rather
Doubt that you will not marry.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Madam by heaven, as fully I am resolved to marry now,
And will to, if you do not hinder it,
As ever lover was, only because
The world has taken notice of some passage
Twixt you and me, and then to satisfy
My sweet heart here, who poor soul is a feared,
To have some public disgrace put upon her,
I do require some small thing at your hands.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Well, I will do it and th●s profess besides,
Married, you shall as welcome be to me
As mine own brother, and yourself fair lady,
Even as myself, both to my board, and bed.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.l: Ah, ah, how like you that?

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Now she begins, abundant thanks unto your widowhood.
sp.l: Zounds my fathers asleep on's wedding day,
I wondered where his cough was all this while.

div.stage: Enter Ingen like a doctor: a parson, brother, provdly, Seldom, mrs.. seld. Husband, wife, and Subtle.

sp.speaker: Ingen.
sp.l: I pray forbear the chamber, noise does hurt her.
Her sickness I guess rather of the mind
Than of her body, for her pulse beats well,
Her vital functions not decayed a whit,
But have their natural life and operation.
My lord, be cheered, I have an ingredient about me,
Shall make her well I doubt not.
In master parson, it shall be yours I pray,
The soul's physician should have still the way.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: How cheers she pray?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: In troth exceeding il● ▪

sp.speaker: Ms. Seld.
sp.l: A very weak woman indeed she is, and surely
I think cannot scape it.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Did you mark how she eyed the physician?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O God I, she is very loath to die.

sp.speaker: Ms. Seld.
sp.l: I that's ne'er the better sign, I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: And when the parson came to her, she turned away,
And still let the physician hold her by the hand.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: But see what thought the bridegroom takes, my conscience knows now, this is a most preposterous match, yet for the commodity, we wink at all inconveniency. My lord, my lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Ump, ump, ump, I beshrew you for waking of me, now shall I have such a fit of coughing, hum, hum —

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.p:
O hapless wife, that shall have thee, that either
must let thee sleep continually, or be kept waking herself by the cough.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: You have a proper gentleman to your son, my
Lord, he were fitter for this young lady than you.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.l: D'ye mark that again?

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.l: O sweet widow.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: He a wife, he a fool's head of his own.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.l: No, of my fathers.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: What should he do with a ump, ump?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What with a cough? why he would spit, and that's more than you can do.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.p: Your bride my lord is dead.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Marry, e'en God be with her, grief will not help it, ump, ump, ump.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: A most excellent spouse.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: How fares she Mr. doctor. 'zounds, what's here
Bold, widow, Well-tried, fee-simple, heyday.
Husband, wife, seldom, Ms. seld. Subtle: how now?

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Look, look, the parson joins the doctor's hand and hers; now the do. kisses her by this light.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Now goes his gown off, heyday, he has read breeches on: zounds, the physician is gotPistols for Bro.o'th top of her, be like it is the mother she has, hark the bed creaks.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: S'hart, the doors fast, break 'em open, we are betrayed.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: No breaking open doors, he that stirs first
sp.stage: Draws and holds out a pistol.
sp.l: I'll pop a leaden pill into his guts.
Shall purge him quite away, no haste good friends,
When they have done (What's fit) you shall not need
To break the door, they'll open it themselves.

div.stage: A curtain drawn, a bed discovered, Ingen with his sword in his hand, and a pistol, the lady in a petticoat, the parson.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Thy blood base villain shall answer this
sp.stage: The Bro. set back to back
sp.l: I'll die thy nuptial bed in thy heart's go●e.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Come, come, my lord, 'tis not so easily done,
You know it is not. For this my attempt
Upon your sister, before God and man
she was my wife, and ne'er a bedrid gout
Shall have my wench, to get diseases on.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Well mayest thou term her so that has consented,
Even with her will to be dishonoured.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Not so, yet have I lyen with her.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: But first (Witness this priest) we both were married,

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: True it is dominae.
Their contract's run into a marriage,
And that my lord into a carriage.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I will undo thee priest.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: 'Tis too late,
I'm undone already, wine and tobacco, I defy thee
Thou temporal lord, perdie thou never shalt
Keep me in jail, and hence springs my reason,
My act is neither felony nor treason.

sp.speaker: Fee.
sp.l: Ay sir, but you do not know, what kindred she may have.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Come, come, there is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: And weight right in my opinion my honoured lord,
And everybody's else, this is a match,
Fitter ten thousand times, than your intent.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Most certain 'tis.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Besides, this gentleman your brother in law well parted, and fair meant, and all this come about (You must conceive) by your own sister's wit as well as his.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Come, come, 'tis but getting of me knighted my
Lord, and I shall become your brother well enough.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Brother your hand, lords may have projects still,
But there's a greater lord, will have his will.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: This is dispatched. Now madam is the time,
For I long to be at it, your hand sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.l: Now, boys.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: My lord, and gentlemen, I crave your witness
To what I now shall utter. Betwixt this gentleman
There has been some love passages and myself,
Which here I free him, and take this lady.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.l: La ye, and take this lady.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Which with a mother's love, I give to him,
And wish all joy may crown their marriage.

sp.speaker: Bould.
sp.l: Nay madam, yet she is not satisfied.
Bold gives her a ring, and she puts it on her thumb.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Further, before ye all I take this ring
As an assumpsit, by the virtue of which
I bind myself in all my lands and goods,
That in his choice, I'll be no hindrance:
Or by forbidding banes, or claiming him
Myself for mine, but let the match go on
Without my check, which he intendeth now.
And once again I say, I bind myself.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Then once again, I say, widow thou'rt mine ▪
Priest marry us, this match I did intend,
Ye are all witnesses, if thou hinder it,
Widow your lands and goods are forfeit mine.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Ha, nay take me to, since there's no remedy,
Your widow (Without goods) sells scurvily.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Whoop, God give you joy.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Slight, I am cozened of all sides, I had good hope of the widow myself, but now I see everybody leaves me saving 'em, umh, umh.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: 'Troth my lord, and that will stick by you I warrant.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: But how sir, shall we salve this gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Hang her whore.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.l: Fie, you are too uncivil.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.l: Whore in thy face, I do defy thy taunts.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Nay hold fair lady, now I think upon't.
The old count has no wife, let's make a match.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: If he be so contented.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Then kiss your spouse.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: 'Sfoot she has a beard: how now, my son?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: 'Tis the lord fee-simple.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Father, lend me your sword, you and I are made a couple of fine fools, are we not? If I were not valiant now, and meant to beat 'em all, here would lie a simple disgrace upon us, a fee-simple one indeed, mark now what I'll say to 'em, d'ye hear my masters, damn, ye are all the son of a whore, and ye lie, and I will make it good with my sword, this is called roaring father.

sp.speaker: Subt.
sp.l: I'll not meddle with you sir.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: You are my blood.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.l: And I fleshed you, you know.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: And I have a charge coming, I must not fight now.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.l: Has either of you any thing to say to me?

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Not we sir.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Then have I something to say to you. Have you any thing to say to me?

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: Yes marry have I sir.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Then I have nothing to say to you, for that's the fashion, father if you will come away with your cough, do? Let me see how many challenges must I get writ: you shall here on me believe it.

sp.speaker: Proud.
sp.l: Nay, we'll not now part angry, stay the feasts
That must attend the weddings, you shall stay.

sp.speaker: Feesi.
sp.p: Why, then all friends, I thought you would not have had the manners to bid us stay dinner neither.

sp.speaker: Husband
sp.l: Then all are friends, and lady, wife, I crown
Thy virtues with this wreath, that 'tmay be said,
There's a good wife.

div.stage: They set garlands on their heads.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: A widow.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: And a maid.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Yet mine is now approved the happiest life,
Since each of you hath changed to be a wife.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
